dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Casual and conversational, but consistently misrepresenting the source material.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, have you been keeping an eye on Shopify? Because, uh, their value has really taken a hit lately, hasn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, have you been keeping an eye on Shopify? Because, uh, their value has really taken a hit lately, hasn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thanks to skyrocketing demand for its online business-building tools, the Ottawa-based e-commerce giant has brought a windfall to its public market investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. I mean, it's pretty wild. Last week it, like, bottomed out at $84 billion, which briefly made it the least valuable company in Canada. Ouch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. I mean, it's pretty wild. Last week it, like, bottomed out at eighty four billion dollars, which briefly made it the least valuable company in Canada. Ouch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Tobias Lutke, their 39-year-old CEO? His net worth, um, dipped south of $6 billion. That's gotta sting a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Tobias Lutke, their thirty nine-year-old C E O? His net worth, um, dipped south of six billion dollars. That's gotta sting a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It does. But, get this, for one of their earliest investors, Bessemer Venture Partners, this whole situation is actually kind of a… boon. Which sounds really counterintuitive, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does. But, get this, for one of their earliest investors, Bessemer Venture Partners, this whole situation is actually kind of a... boon. Which sounds really counterintuitive, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for one of its earliest investors, San Francisco-based Bessemer Venture Partners, the hype around the company is bittersweet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really does! So, tell me, how exactly is Shopify struggling good for an early investor?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really does! So, tell me, how exactly is Shopify struggling good for an early investor?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they initially poured $5.5 million into Shopify's initial funding round back in 2010. And by the time it went public in 2015, they held a 26% stake worth, like, half a billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they initially poured five point five million dollars into Shopify's initial funding round back in twenty ten. And by the time it went public in twenty fifteen, they held a twenty six percent stake worth, like, half a billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm first invested $5.5 million in the companys initial funding round, and after additional investments built a 26% stake worth $500 million when it went public in 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's already a massive return. But then what happened?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's already a massive return. But then what happened?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: This is where it gets interesting. Contrary to what most VC firms do – which is hold on and then cash out post-IPO – Bessemer actually increased their shares back to their partners by the end of 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This is where it gets interesting. Contrary to what most V C firms do - which is hold on and then cash out post-I P O - Bessemer actually increased their shares back to their partners by the end of twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...Bessemer had redistributed all its shares back to its partners by the end of 2018, when the company was worth $15 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And at that point, Shopify was "only" worth $15 billion. The article says that today, Bessemer's stake *would* be worth close to $22 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And at that point, Shopify was only worth fifteen billion dollars. The article says that today, Bessemer's stake would be worth close to twenty two billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...Bessemer had redistributed all its shares back to its partners by the end of 2018, when the company was worth $15 billion. ... Today Bessemers stake would currently be worth close to $22 billion, the firm says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. So by staying in for just two more years, they left, like, $17 billion on the table? That's… that's insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. So by staying in for just two more years, they left, like, seventeen billion dollars on the table? That's... that's insane.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By exiting Shopify two years ago, Bessemer left at least $17 billion on the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know! But, you know, Bessemer partner Alex Ferrara, who led that initial funding round, he says he can comprehend "that they would have this massive amount of failure at that time."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! But, you know, Bessemer partner Alex Ferrara, who led that initial funding round, he says he can comprehend that they would have this massive amount of failure at that time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I couldnt comprehend that they would have this massive amount of success at that time, says Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led Shopifys initial funding round in 2010.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Even though it's a 'failure' in terms of missed opportunity, it's still considered a huge success in venture investing, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even though it's a failure in terms of missed opportunity, it's still considered a huge success in venture investing, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Will Gornal, a professor at UBC, points out that VCs are typically under pressure to post losses on investments in private startups within 5 to 10 years. So, it's common to buy shares back from their own investors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Will Gornal, a professor at U B C, points out that V Cs are typically under pressure to post losses on investments in private startups within five to ten years. So, it's common to buy shares back from their own investors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Venture capital funds are typically under pressure to post returns on investments in private startups over a relatively short period of time, between five and 10 years, says Gornal. Once a company goes public, a venture firm will often sell its shares back to its own investors...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And that often gives those investors the option to hold or cash out. So, while Bessemer didn't get that $17 billion, they still made a huge amount for their partners.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And that often gives those investors the option to hold or cash out. So, while Bessemer didn't get that seventeen billion dollars, they still made a huge amount for their partners.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...giving them the option to hold their stake in the company or cash out. ... While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they say they'll 'reluctantly take its realized losses,' which actually translates to, like, an 80 to 100 times return on their initial investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they say they'll reluctantly take its realized losses, which actually translates to, like, an eighty to one hundred times return on their initial investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, that's still a crystal ball kind of win, even with the 'missed' twenty-two billion, uh, I guess. What a story!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, that's still a crystal ball kind of win, even with the missed twenty-two billion, uh, I guess. What a story!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Says the venture capitalist: We didnt have a crystal ball.
